column1: # Although the expression "angel of God" here uses Elohim rather than YHWH, the words spoken
# suggest that this is in fact the voice of God, which can then be treated as a theophany (which
# may lead the casting director to assign this character to the same actor who does the
# voice of Jesus or to the actor who does God). Of course, it can also be casted as a "normal"
# angel who is understood to be speaking God's very words. In any case, this is a casting decision
# and not an actual ambiguity in the text.

column1: # Almost all translators agree that vv. 31-32 are commentary by the narrator, but at least one project
# continues the quote and has Moses speak these words to Pharaoh.
# In a few of the following chapters, FCBH has God speak all the way through the end. However,
# some other translations have God's speech end earlier, with the final verse(s) in each section
# being a summary (spoken by the narrator). So rather than forcing these questionable places to
# be Implicit, we use "Potential" quotes for these verses, so that the quote parser will assign
# it properly if explicit quotes are used in the text. The reference text will have them set
# explicitly according to FCBH's interpretation, but the scripter can look at these places and
# choose to assign them to narrator if that is preferable.

column1: # Because of the difficult textual/translation issue in v. 1, if there are not explicit
# quotes, it should be reviewed. The English reference text takes the traditional interpretation,
# but even in that interpretation, the portion following the colon could be spoken by Agur
# Including this for now since that's how FCBH dramatizes this:
# Unfortunately, if this hypothetical speech is in first-level quotes (which is likely), it
# will mess up the logic that makes this whole verse implicitly spoken by King Lemuel's mother.
# In any case, we don't want to dramatize it as being spoken by the princes, so we'll omit this:
# Including this for now since that's how FCBH dramatizes this:
# Including this for now since that's how FCBH dramatizes this:
# Although King Solomon is generally accepted as the author (i.e., the teacher/preacher) of
# Ecclesiastes, since he is not named by name, an alternate character ID is provided as an option.
# This verse used to be given implicitly to God based on the wording. There is nothing in the text that
# appears to make it a quote, unless you make everything from 4-15a a quote by God. Many English translations
# do put v. 4 in quotes and a few of the less literal ones add a reporting clause. Since the WEB does not do this,
# the English reference text now keeps it as narrator (Isaiah). (As the prophet, he can certainly speak on God's
# behalf.) By implicitly marking this verse as Needs Review, it should get the required scrutiny.

column4: Syria/Ephraim/Pekah, son of Remaliah, king of Israel

# God is speaking. Nonetheless, the ISV does explicitly attribute it to God.

column1: # Although this is a "cannot say", since the craftsman is speaking in the preceding verses,
# it may sound good to have him say this part also.
# Not sure how to handle this. What we really want is: if we find a quote, then it can be unambiguously assigned
# to God. But if we don't, then mark the verse for review to see if it should be split.
# If the text has the hypothetical speech by the Egyptians, Ethiopians and Sabeans continue through v. 15 and the
# scripter wants to have God speak it, then He needs to be an option in this verse.
# We definitely want the quotes in vv. 3, 6, 7 & 8 to be recorded by God, but some translations
# (e.g., ISV) might have these as 2nd level quotes.
# This is a self-quote by the narator, speaking prophetically on behalf of God's servant
# (named in the passage as "Israel", but presumably the Messiah):
# Some translations consider that God continues to speak in v. 13-14
# If there is a quote (God) midway through v. 11, the preceding part should
# be the narrator. Otherwise, the whole verse should be spoken by God.

# verses contain 3rd-person references to God, even though the whole thing is almost certainly to be spoken by God.
# Verses 14-33 seem to break out of the letter and switch into 3rd-person narration mode, but presumably the
# whole account was included in Nebuchadnezzar's letter, so the control file includes Alternate and Potential
# entries to allow for the whole account to be related as a single letter. See CJB for an example of a Bible
# that wraps quotes around everything from v. 1b to the end of the chapter (though even then you might not
# choose to dramatize it that way).

column1: # The quoted text in v.15 could be treated as a Hypothetical quote instead, but since it is not

# and it won't interfere with the treatment of this discourse as implicitly spoken by God.
# FCBH has God speak all the way through 12:14, which seems probable, but some Bibles that use explicit quotes end them at v. 10.
#It is confusing if those speaking are the idolaters or if they are speaking of the idolaters, but since FCBH doesn't
#want this to be spoken by the "Ephraim" character (see 12:8), it doesn't really matter, so we'll use a single generic

column1: # The grammar and/or narrative style in the target language might influence whether this
# can/should be spoken by Jesus or related as a quotation of his words by the narrator.
# Some translations consider that Paul's self-quote ends with v.14. Others have him speak through v. 21
# Narrator should definitely speak at least the quote of what God doesn't say.

# Use of quote in vv. 17-18 is rare. If it occurs, most likely it should be read by the narrator/author (Paul). But since he is telling Timothy what to say, a possible alternative would be to have a different character (Timothy) read the quote. Data integrity rules don't allow Alternate type to be used, but AdjustData will make this into an alternate.
# Speaker of the target language may need to review whether it is acceptable to
# combine the two quotes into one "scripture" block. For languages with a single "and"
# joining them, this will probably sound fine, but for languages that have a longer
# clause introducing the second quote, this might not work.
